column8: Check use of blank spaces before and after the equal sign (=) throughout the document. Various conventions are found: blank space after, blank space before and after, no blank space add all > I'd suggest using blank space before and after = throughout the document.
I think, Figure 11.2 (not 11.1) needs to be referred to here.
This is not reflected in Figure 11.2. For JJS, the Munit of PE is also higher than the Munit of TfS.
But Figure 11.2 shows for POS, that the Munit value for MPE is also higher than the Munit value for Tfs. So POS is no exception.
The cross-references to chapters and section are sometimes not clear. I suggest using chapter numbers and section numbers throughout the book, e.g. Chapter 9 and Chapter 10.
You sometimes use 'TPR-DB', sometimes 'TPR database' in the book.
Use 'Text 5' rather than 'text five' (see, e.g., use of reference 'Text 2' earlier in the paragraph)
It seems to me that past tense, present tense, will future is used consistently throughout this chapter (book?) - can a native speaker help?

I find the abbreviations for the parts of speech very difficult to memorize. It is unclear why no transparent abbreviations were chosen. Example: An adjective is 'JJ', a particle 'RB, a noun in the plural(!) form is 'NNS' as opposed to a singular noun, which is 'NN'.
no statistical difference > no statistically significant difference
Check 'e.g.' and 'e. g.' throughout the document. Remove blank space before 'g'.
Figure 11.2 does not show that Munit is higher in MPE than PE for JJS. However, for *WDT*, Munit is higher for MPE than PE. Consider revising this paragraph.
superlative of an adjective > superlative adjective
Tables IV.1 and IV.2 > Tables D.1 and D.2
Elsewhere the particle category is referred as RP (see e.g. Appendix D, Figure 11.1, Figure 11.2).
'Cf.' is used used in front of in-text citations throughout the text. Consider deleting.
What is meant by 'In the following chapters'? - In Sections 11.2.1, 11.2.2 and 11.2.3?
It is not clear to me why this is stated at this point.
What is meant by 'following chapter'? This chapter (= Chapter 11)?
Two subsequent sentences starting with 'however', consider rephrasing.
Recall my comment on the use of blank spaces with '='. I do not mark this inconsistency in the remainder of Chapter 11, but please check.
Recall my comment on the use of blank spaces with '<'. I do not mark this inconsistency in the remainder of Chapter 11, but please check.
Can Figures 11.1 and 11.2 be present *earlier* in Section 11.2.1, e.g. before or soon after this paragraph where they are referred to the first time?

The style of this chapter really requires editing. The sentence structure is often not clear. But as a non-native speaker of English I don't want to propose any corrections or improvements. Can a native speaker help?
Check use of blank spaces with the '<' symbol, sometimes blank space after, sometimes blank space before and after, sometimes no space at all. I propose using blank space before and after.
Place footnote symbols consistently after full stops. Check the whole document.
Not clear what the author means by 'particle'. On p. 117, German '-mals' on 'oftmals' is considered a particle as well as 'auch'. Here English 'up' is considered a particle. Clarify.
What would change if you simply wrote 'editing' or only 'reviewing'?

But not only these PoS classes were modified more often in PE than in MPE. If one looks at Figure 11.2, then actually all PoS classes were modified more often in PE than in MPE - the only exceptions are RBR, VBD and WDT.
Use italics for object-language forms here and elsewhere in the document.
Shift full stop to position after bracket.
then substract the value 1 for TfS, as well > then substract again the value 1 for TfS
These are more than a 'couple' of exceptions! Why is JJR in the list and not, say, JJS where there is also a significant difference between PE and MPE.
'PRP' stands for 'personal pronouns', not for 'comparative adverbs' (see Appendix D.
The figures are really hard to read and it is impossible to imagine a threshold of 0.2, if the smallest value indicated by a line in the figure is 0.5.
All the figures in Chapter 11 (possibly also beyond!) need to be revised as the decimal numbers are everywhere written according to the German (1,6) and not the English convention (1.6).

column8: I find it extremely inconvenient that the table is given in the appendix and not here.
Is there not a significant difference between the InEff values of POS for TfS and PE/MPE in Table D.2. I am confused ...
Heterogenous list: one NP and two sentences are here coordinated
I do see a significant difference between TfS and MPE for CS in Table D.2.
What about WDT, which also has a value below 1, as Figure 11.6 shows.
I doubt that the use of personal pronouns (PRP!) is very low in the texts.

It is unclear to me why all these categories are mentioned as illustrating a similar value in TfS + PE value or a higher value in PE than in TfS. The values for VBN are in fact fairly close, but I don't see why VBG (TfS higher), VBP (Tfs higher) and WP (TfS higher) are mentioned here.
I suggest using single quotation marks for the literal translation (as already indicated previously in this chapter).
different verb positioning > different position of the verb
You write here 'influence on production time [= which is Dur], excluding [...] and Dur'. This does not make sense.
SD > sd  (see rest of the document)
